Kuru is an incurable degenerative neurological disorder endemic to tribal regions of Papua New Guinea. It is a type of transmissible spongiform encephalopathy, caused by a prion found in humans. The symptoms of kuru are divided into three specific stages. The first, ambulant stage, exhibits unsteady stance and gait, decreased muscle control, tremors, deterioration of speech, and dysarthria (slurred speech).

Definition. Kuru is the name of a progressively disabling and ultimately fatal brain infection caused by a unique protein particle called a prion. Kuru was first described in a specific tribal group in Papua, New Guinea. The word kuru means to shake or tremble in this tribal group's language. Individuals in New Guinea are believed to have acquired the infection through a cannibalistic ritual involving the blood and brains of deceased tribal members.

Kuru is an extremely rare and fatal nervous system disease. The disease reached its peak during the 1950s and 1960s among the Fore people in the highlands of New Guinea. Kuru developed from the people of New Guinea eating brains of dead relatives during funeral rites. Women and children were of the majority infected with kuru. This is because they were the primary participants in the funerary rituals. The New Guinea government has discouraged the practice of cannibalism.

The term kuru derives from the Fore word kuria/guria (to shake), a reference to the body tremors that are a classic symptom of the disease; it is also known among the Fore as the laughing sickness due to the pathologic bursts of laughter people would display when afflicted with the disease. Prion-caused diseases such as kuru occur due to an accumulation of a disease-related iosoform of host-encoded prion proteins through a posttranslational process involving a conformational change and aggregation (1). This irregular prion protein isoform is believed to be the primary cause of kuru's infectious prion (1). Primarily, the women of the Fore were most affected from the consumption of the brain. Kuru became the most common cause of death in women of childbearing age (2). However, approximately two percent of men were affected from the disease (2).
